Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analysis of Bacterial Catabolism of Plant Biomass- A Phenomenon with Special Relevance to Environmental Carbon Cycling and Alternative Energy

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Life on Earth depends on the consumption of plant biomass by microorganisms. While soil-dwelling microorganisms degrade and consume tremendous amounts of plant biomass, we know little about how they do it. This is an important process for study, and an improved understanding of the metabolism could lead to strategies for the production of high value chemicals and/or fuels from low cost and abundant plant biomass. This CAREER project is focused on elucidating mechanisms of plant biomass consumption by bacteria. Most of the published research on plant biomass consumption has been focused on higher microorganisms (fungi), and this bacterial-focused research project will provide interesting and useful counterpoints to our current understanding of microbial metabolism.

Broader impacts
This research project will provide educational and training opportunities for graduate students and undergraduates who are working with the principal investigator. In the first four years of his independent career at Brown University, the PI trained six graduate students and twenty undergraduates. Similar numbers of trainees will be involved with this project. Beyond the activities at Brown, an integral component of the project is a research/education partnership with teachers and ethnically diverse students at high schools in Providence, Rhode Island and in Brown University-sponsored summer programs. The principal investigator has also formed a partnership with his alma mater, Morehouse College, America's only all male, historically black college to involve additional individuals from under-represented groups in the research project. This partnership involves annual trips to Morehouse College for mentoring activities and opportunities for Morehouse students to carry out research at Brown University during the summers. In addition to training future scientists, the outreach activities in this project will enhance public awareness of science. The findings of the project will contribute to environmental science and the development of new alternative energy technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mankind’s survival and well-being are inextricably linked to the health of the environment. Thus, it is absolutely essential that we sustain the environment as we engage in the activities that enable our survival and well-being. One objective in “sustainability” is to convert cheap and readily abundant plant biomass into commodity chemicals like biofuels or drugs. Accordingly, my trainees, collaborators and I have been studying a group of soil-dwelling bacteria that are consumers of plant biomass and producers of more than two-thirds of the antibiotics used as drugs for the treatment of cancer and infectious diseases and for immunosuppression in organ transplantation. It is our contention that these actinobacteria can be used in a biotechnological platform through which plant biomass can be converted into high-value commodities. This viewpoint is justified by the long history of these bacteria in the pharmaceutical industry wherein they are fermented to produce some of our most important medicines.

In an effort to understand how actinobacteria consume plant biomass, we sequenced the genomes of two biomass-degrading species- Streptomyces viridosporus and Amycolatopsis setonii. Within these genetic blueprints, we identified genes underlying the central metabolic pathway that the bacteria use for the consumption of lignin, a polymer that constitutes as much as 30% of plant biomass. These genes are of interest because they encode enzymes that transform this neglected component of plant biomass into the biochemical building blocks of both biofuels and antibiotics. Using Streptomyces coelicolor (a genetically tractable model of the biomass-degrading bacteria), we discovered that this pathway is tightly regulated at the genetic level by two transcription factors that we have named PcaV and PobR. Using biochemical experiments, we determined that PcaV binds DNA and turns off the pathway’s gene under most conditions. Further, we found that PcaV is released from DNA and the genes of the lignin consumption pathway are turned on when the bacteria are grown in the presence of depolymerized lignin. We have gained an in-depth understanding of how this switch works by elucidating the structure of PcaV at the atomic level. In a parallel line of investigations, we characterized the pobR gene in S. coelicolor and its product. This gene is highly unusual in that it is an apparent translational fusion of two transcriptional factors. As was the case for PcaV, we found that PobR represses gene expression by binding to DNA with high affinity. We determined that the affinity of PobR for DNA is markedly attenuated by its interaction with a lignin-depolymerization product that is catabolized via the metabolic pathway regulated by PobR. These observations, coupled with a high-resolution crystal structure of the protein in complex with its ligand, explain how PobR regulates the expression of genes underlying lignin catabolism. We are now using our understanding of this pathway to engineer bacteria for the efficient conversion of plant biomass to commodity chemicals.

Impact and Benefits:

We have generated new knowledge that yields a basis for a biotechnological platform for the conversion of plant biomass to commodity chemicals. Such a platform would be part of a growing set of alternative energy and sustainability technologies. Through the research, five graduate students and ten undergraduates have received empowering training with in the life sciences. These individuals have gone on to work in academic and industrial positions and to further their education in Ph.D. programs or medical school. The impact of this work is both broadened and made more immediate by the courses that we developed and implemented to teach high school teacher and students about the importance of microorganisms in the environment. The students have also impacted our research efforts via the collection of soil samples from which we isolated bacterial strains for our studies.
